text_entry: His greatness is a-ripening, nips his root,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: And then he falls, as I do. I have ventured,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Like little wanton boys that swim on bladders,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: This many summers in a sea of glory,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: But far beyond my depth: my high-blown pride

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: At length broke under me and now has left me,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Weary and old with service, to the mercy

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Of a rude stream, that must for ever hide me.

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Vain pomp and glory of this world, I hate ye:

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: I feel my heart new open'd. O, how wretched

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Is that poor man that hangs on princes' favours!

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: There is, betwixt that smile we would aspire to,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: That sweet aspect of princes, and their ruin,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: More pangs and fears than wars or women have:

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: And when he falls, he falls like Lucifer,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Never to hope again.

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Enter CROMWELL, and stands amazed

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Why, how now, Cromwell!

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: I have no power to speak, sir.

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: What, amazed

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: At my misfortunes? can thy spirit wonder

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: A great man should decline? Nay, an you weep,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: I am fall'n indeed.

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: How does your grace?

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Why, well;

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Never so truly happy, my good Cromwell.

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: I know myself now; and I feel within me

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: A peace above all earthly dignities,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: A still and quiet conscience. The king has cured me,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: I humbly thank his grace; and from these shoulders,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: These ruin'd pillars, out of pity, taken

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: A load would sink a navy, too much honour:

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: O, 'tis a burthen, Cromwell, 'tis a burthen

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Too heavy for a man that hopes for heaven!

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: I am glad your grace has made that right use of it.

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: I hope I have: I am able now, methinks,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Out of a fortitude of soul I feel,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: To endure more miseries and greater far

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Than my weak-hearted enemies dare offer.

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: What news abroad?

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: The heaviest and the worst

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: Is your displeasure with the king.

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: God bless him!

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: The next is, that Sir Thomas More is chosen

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: Lord chancellor in your place.

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: That's somewhat sudden:

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: But he's a learned man. May he continue

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Long in his highness' favour, and do justice

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: For truth's sake and his conscience; that his bones,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: When he has run his course and sleeps in blessings,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: May have a tomb of orphans' tears wept on em! What more?

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: That Cranmer is return'd with welcome,

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: Install'd lord archbishop of Canterbury.

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: That's news indeed.

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: Last, that the Lady Anne,

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: Whom the king hath in secrecy long married,

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: This day was view'd in open as his queen,

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: Going to chapel; and the voice is now

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: Only about her coronation.

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: There was the weight that pull'd me down. O Cromwell,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: The king has gone beyond me: all my glories

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: In that one woman I have lost for ever:

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: No sun shall ever usher forth mine honours,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Or gild again the noble troops that waited

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Upon my smiles. Go, get thee from me, Cromwell;

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: I am a poor fall'n man, unworthy now

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: To be thy lord and master: seek the king;

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: That sun, I pray, may never set! I have told him

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: What and how true thou art: he will advance thee;

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Some little memory of me will stir him--

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: I know his noble nature--not to let

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Thy hopeful service perish too: good Cromwell,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Neglect him not; make use now, and provide

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: For thine own future safety.

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: O my lord,

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: Must I, then, leave you? must I needs forego

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: So good, so noble and so true a master?

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: Bear witness, all that have not hearts of iron,

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: With what a sorrow Cromwell leaves his lord.

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: The king shall have my service: but my prayers

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: For ever and for ever shall be yours.

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Cromwell, I did not think to shed a tear

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: In all my miseries; but thou hast forced me,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Out of thy honest truth, to play the woman.

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Let's dry our eyes: and thus far hear me, Cromwell;

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: And, when I am forgotten, as I shall be,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: And sleep in dull cold marble, where no mention

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Of me more must be heard of, say, I taught thee,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Say, Wolsey, that once trod the ways of glory,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: And sounded all the depths and shoals of honour,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Found thee a way, out of his wreck, to rise in;

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: A sure and safe one, though thy master miss'd it.

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Mark but my fall, and that that ruin'd me.

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Cromwell, I charge thee, fling away ambition:

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: By that sin fell the angels; how can man, then,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: The image of his Maker, hope to win by it?

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Love thyself last: cherish those hearts that hate thee;

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Corruption wins not more than honesty.

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Still in thy right hand carry gentle peace,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: To silence envious tongues. Be just, and fear not:

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Let all the ends thou aim'st at be thy country's,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Thy God's, and truth's; then if thou fall'st,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: O Cromwell,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Thou fall'st a blessed martyr! Serve the king;

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: And,--prithee, lead me in:

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: There take an inventory of all I have,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: To the last penny; 'tis the king's: my robe,

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: And my integrity to heaven, is all

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: I dare now call mine own. O Cromwell, Cromwell!

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Had I but served my God with half the zeal

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: I served my king, he would not in mine age

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Have left me naked to mine enemies.

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: Good sir, have patience.

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: So I have. Farewell

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: The hopes of court! my hopes in heaven do dwell.

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Duchess of Norfolk, and Lady Marquess Dorset: will

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: these please you?

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Once more, my Lord of Winchester, I charge you,

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Embrace and love this man.

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: With a true heart

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: And brother-love I do it.

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: And let heaven

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Witness, how dear I hold this confirmation.

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Good man, those joyful tears show thy true heart:

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: The common voice, I see, is verified

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Of thee, which says thus, 'Do my Lord of Canterbury

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: A shrewd turn, and he is your friend for ever.'

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Come, lords, we trifle time away; I long

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: To have this young one made a Christian.

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: As I have made ye one, lords, one remain;

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: So I grow stronger, you more honour gain.

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: SCENE IV. The palace yard.

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Noise and tumult within. Enter Porter and his Man

speaker: Porter
text_entry: You'll leave your noise anon, ye rascals: do you

speaker: Porter
text_entry: take the court for Paris-garden? ye rude slaves,

speaker: Porter
text_entry: leave your gaping.

speaker: Porter
text_entry: Within

speaker: Porter
text_entry: Good master porter, I belong to the larder.

speaker: Porter
text_entry: Belong to the gallows, and be hanged, ye rogue! is

speaker: Porter
text_entry: this a place to roar in? Fetch me a dozen crab-tree

speaker: Porter
text_entry: staves, and strong ones: these are but switches to

speaker: Porter
text_entry: 'em. I'll scratch your heads: you must be seeing

speaker: Porter
text_entry: christenings? do you look for ale and cakes here,

speaker: Porter
text_entry: you rude rascals?

speaker: Man
text_entry: Pray, sir, be patient: 'tis as much impossible--

speaker: Man
text_entry: Unless we sweep 'em from the door with cannons--

speaker: Man
text_entry: To scatter 'em, as 'tis to make 'em sleep

speaker: Man
text_entry: On May-day morning; which will never be:

speaker: Man
text_entry: We may as well push against Powle's, as stir em.

speaker: Porter
text_entry: How got they in, and be hang'd?

speaker: Man
text_entry: Alas, I know not; how gets the tide in?

speaker: Man
text_entry: As much as one sound cudgel of four foot--

speaker: Man
text_entry: You see the poor remainder--could distribute,

speaker: Man
text_entry: I made no spare, sir.

speaker: Porter
text_entry: You did nothing, sir.

speaker: Man
text_entry: I am not Samson, nor Sir Guy, nor Colbrand,

speaker: Man
text_entry: To mow 'em down before me: but if I spared any

speaker: Man
text_entry: That had a head to hit, either young or old,

speaker: Man
text_entry: He or she, cuckold or cuckold-maker,

speaker: Man
text_entry: Let me ne'er hope to see a chine again

speaker: Man
text_entry: And that I would not for a cow, God save her!

speaker: Man
text_entry: Within

speaker: Man
text_entry: Do you hear, master porter?

speaker: Porter
text_entry: I shall be with you presently, good master puppy.

speaker: Porter
text_entry: Keep the door close, sirrah.

speaker: Man
text_entry: What would you have me do?

speaker: Porter
text_entry: What should you do, but knock 'em down by the

speaker: Porter
text_entry: dozens? Is this Moorfields to muster in? or have

speaker: Porter
text_entry: we some strange Indian with the great tool come to

speaker: Porter
text_entry: court, the women so besiege us? Bless me, what a

speaker: Porter
text_entry: fry of fornication is at door! On my Christian

speaker: Porter
text_entry: conscience, this one christening will beget a

speaker: Porter
text_entry: thousand; here will be father, godfather, and all together.

speaker: Man
text_entry: The spoons will be the bigger, sir. There is a

speaker: Man
text_entry: fellow somewhat near the door, he should be a

speaker: Man
text_entry: brazier by his face, for, o' my conscience, twenty

speaker: Man
text_entry: of the dog-days now reign in's nose; all that stand

speaker: Man
text_entry: about him are under the line, they need no other

speaker: Man
text_entry: penance: that fire-drake did I hit three times on

speaker: Man
text_entry: the head, and three times was his nose discharged

speaker: Man
text_entry: against me; he stands there, like a mortar-piece, to

speaker: Man
text_entry: blow us. There was a haberdasher's wife of small

speaker: Man
text_entry: wit near him, that railed upon me till her pinked

speaker: Man
text_entry: porringer fell off her head, for kindling such a

speaker: Man
text_entry: combustion in the state. I missed the meteor once,

speaker: Man
text_entry: and hit that woman; who cried out 'Clubs!' when I

speaker: Man
text_entry: might see from far some forty truncheoners draw to

speaker: Man
text_entry: her succor, which were the hope o' the Strand, where

speaker: Man
text_entry: she was quartered. They fell on; I made good my

speaker: Man
text_entry: place: at length they came to the broom-staff to

speaker: Man
text_entry: me; I defied 'em still: when suddenly a file of

speaker: Man
text_entry: boys behind 'em, loose shot, delivered such a shower

speaker: Man
text_entry: of pebbles, that I was fain to draw mine honour in,

speaker: Man
text_entry: and let 'em win the work: the devil was amongst

speaker: Man
text_entry: 'em, I think, surely.

speaker: Porter
text_entry: These are the youths that thunder at a playhouse,

speaker: Porter
text_entry: and fight for bitten apples; that no audience, but

speaker: Porter
text_entry: the tribulation of Tower-hill, or the limbs of

speaker: Porter
text_entry: Limehouse, their dear brothers, are able to endure.

speaker: Porter
text_entry: I have some of 'em in Limbo Patrum, and there they

speaker: Porter
text_entry: are like to dance these three days; besides the

speaker: Porter
text_entry: running banquet of two beadles that is to come.

speaker: Porter
text_entry: Enter Chamberlain

speaker: Chamberlain
text_entry: Mercy o' me, what a multitude are here!

speaker: Chamberlain
text_entry: They grow still too; from all parts they are coming,

speaker: Chamberlain
text_entry: As if we kept a fair here! Where are these porters,

speaker: Chamberlain
text_entry: These lazy knaves? Ye have made a fine hand, fellows:

speaker: Chamberlain
text_entry: There's a trim rabble let in: are all these

speaker: Chamberlain
text_entry: Your faithful friends o' the suburbs? We shall have

speaker: Chamberlain
text_entry: Great store of room, no doubt, left for the ladies,

speaker: Chamberlain
text_entry: When they pass back from the christening.

speaker: Porter
text_entry: An't please

speaker: Porter
text_entry: your honour,

speaker: Porter
text_entry: We are but men; and what so many may do,

speaker: Porter
text_entry: Not being torn a-pieces, we have done:

speaker: Porter
text_entry: An army cannot rule 'em.

speaker: Chamberlain
text_entry: As I live,

speaker: Chamberlain
text_entry: If the king blame me for't, I'll lay ye all

speaker: Chamberlain
text_entry: By the heels, and suddenly; and on your heads

speaker: Chamberlain
text_entry: Clap round fines for neglect: ye are lazy knaves;

speaker: Chamberlain
text_entry: And here ye lie baiting of bombards, when

speaker: Chamberlain
text_entry: Ye should do service. Hark! the trumpets sound;

speaker: Chamberlain
text_entry: They're come already from the christening:

speaker: Chamberlain
text_entry: Go, break among the press, and find a way out

speaker: Chamberlain
text_entry: To let the troop pass fairly; or I'll find

speaker: Chamberlain
text_entry: A Marshalsea shall hold ye play these two months.

speaker: Porter
text_entry: Make way there for the princess.

speaker: Man
text_entry: You great fellow,

speaker: Man
text_entry: Stand close up, or I'll make your head ache.

speaker: Porter
text_entry: You i' the camlet, get up o' the rail;

speaker: Porter
text_entry: I'll peck you o'er the pales else.

speaker: Porter
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Porter
text_entry: SCENE V. The palace.

speaker: Porter
text_entry: Enter trumpets, sounding; then two Aldermen, Lord  Mayor, Garter, CRANMER, NORFOLK with his marshal's  staff, SUFFOLK, two Noblemen bearing great  standing-bowls for the christening-gifts; then  four Noblemen bearing a canopy, under which the  Duchess of Norfolk, godmother, bearing the child  richly habited in a mantle,  and c., train borne by a  Lady; then follows the Marchioness Dorset, the  other godmother, and Ladies. The troop pass once about the stage, and Garter speaks

speaker: Garter
text_entry: Heaven, from thy endless goodness, send prosperous

speaker: Garter
text_entry: life, long, and ever happy, to the high and mighty

speaker: Garter
text_entry: princess of England, Elizabeth!

speaker: Garter
text_entry: Flourish. Enter KING HENRY VIII and Guard

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: [Kneeling] And to your royal grace, and the good queen,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: My noble partners, and myself, thus pray:

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: All comfort, joy, in this most gracious lady,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Heaven ever laid up to make parents happy,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: May hourly fall upon ye!

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Thank you, good lord archbishop:

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: What is her name?

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Elizabeth.

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Stand up, lord.

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: KING HENRY VIII kisses the child

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: With this kiss take my blessing: God protect thee!

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Into whose hand I give thy life.

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Amen.

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: My noble gossips, ye have been too prodigal:

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: I thank ye heartily; so shall this lady,

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: When she has so much English.

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Let me speak, sir,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: For heaven now bids me; and the words I utter

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Let none think flattery, for they'll find 'em truth.

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: This royal infant--heaven still move about her!--

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Though in her cradle, yet now promises

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Upon this land a thousand thousand blessings,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Which time shall bring to ripeness: she shall be--

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: But few now living can behold that goodness--

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: A pattern to all princes living with her,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: And all that shall succeed: Saba was never

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: More covetous of wisdom and fair virtue

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Than this pure soul shall be: all princely graces,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: That mould up such a mighty piece as this is,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: With all the virtues that attend the good,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Shall still be doubled on her: truth shall nurse her,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Holy and heavenly thoughts still counsel her:

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: She shall be loved and fear'd: her own shall bless her;

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Her foes shake like a field of beaten corn,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: And hang their heads with sorrow: good grows with her:

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: In her days every man shall eat in safety,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Under his own vine, what he plants; and sing

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: The merry songs of peace to all his neighbours:

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: God shall be truly known; and those about her

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: From her shall read the perfect ways of honour,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: And by those claim their greatness, not by blood.

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Nor shall this peace sleep with her: but as when

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: The bird of wonder dies, the maiden phoenix,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Her ashes new create another heir,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: As great in admiration as herself;

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: So shall she leave her blessedness to one,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: When heaven shall call her from this cloud of darkness,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Who from the sacred ashes of her honour

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Shall star-like rise, as great in fame as she was,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: And so stand fix'd: peace, plenty, love, truth, terror,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: That were the servants to this chosen infant,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Shall then be his, and like a vine grow to him:

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Wherever the bright sun of heaven shall shine,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: His honour and the greatness of his name

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Shall be, and make new nations: he shall flourish,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: And, like a mountain cedar, reach his branches

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: To all the plains about him: our children's children

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Shall see this, and bless heaven.

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Thou speakest wonders.

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: She shall be, to the happiness of England,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: An aged princess; many days shall see her,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: And yet no day without a deed to crown it.

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Would I had known no more! but she must die,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: She must, the saints must have her; yet a virgin,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: A most unspotted lily shall she pass

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: To the ground, and all the world shall mourn her.

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: O lord archbishop,

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Thou hast made me now a man! never, before

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: This happy child, did I get any thing:

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: This oracle of comfort has so pleased me,

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: That when I am in heaven I shall desire

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: To see what this child does, and praise my Maker.

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: I thank ye all. To you, my good lord mayor,

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: And your good brethren, I am much beholding;

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: I have received much honour by your presence,

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: And ye shall find me thankful. Lead the way, lords:

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Ye must all see the queen, and she must thank ye,

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: She will be sick else. This day, no man think

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Has business at his house; for all shall stay:

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: This little one shall make it holiday.

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: EPILOGUE

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: 'Tis ten to one this play can never please

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: All that are here: some come to take their ease,

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: And sleep an act or two; but those, we fear,

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: We have frighted with our trumpets; so, 'tis clear,

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: They'll say 'tis naught: others, to hear the city

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Abused extremely, and to cry 'That's witty!'

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Which we have not done neither: that, I fear,

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: All the expected good we're like to hear

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: For this play at this time, is only in

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: The merciful construction of good women;

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: For such a one we show'd 'em: if they smile,

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: And say 'twill do, I know, within a while

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: All the best men are ours; for 'tis ill hap,

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: If they hold when their ladies bid 'em clap.
